summary: Email chain between U.S. prosecutors and the Office of International Affairs (OIA) regarding travel to Sweden to interview a witness in the Jeffrey Epstein sex crimes investigation. The emails discuss the need for a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request, coordination with Swedish authorities, and the sensitive nature of the investigation.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The sender of the initial email requesting OIA concurrence for travel to Sweden to interview a witness in the Epstein case.

events.title: Planned Sweden travel for witness interview
events.description: Prosecutors from the Southern District of New York planned to travel to Sweden to conduct a consensual, voluntary interview with a witness in the Epstein investigation.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

events.title: MLAT request drafted for Sweden interview
events.description: Prosecutors attached a draft Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty request to facilitate the interview in Sweden, following discussions with Swedish authorities.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

keyFacts: The document reveals an active U.S. investigation into Epstein-related sex crimes as of January 2020, focusing on transportation of minors for illicit sexual conduct under 18 U.S.C. 2423.
Prosecutors sought to interview a witness in Sweden who was described as not a conspirator or 'bad actor' and where no victims were believed to be Swedish residents.
The investigation was described as 'extraordinarily sensitive,' leading prosecutors to avoid MLAT requests where possible to limit information sharing with foreign governments.
Swedish law enforcement required prosecutor involvement for the interview, triggering the need for an MLAT request despite the interview being voluntary.
The email chain shows coordination issues between the FBI Legat and Swedish authorities regarding interview approval procedures.
